In the centre but far from the noises and endless traffic of Colombo city, the museum offers a very diverse approach to Sri Lankan history. It is a large and varied museum with pieces by theme. We spent 2 hours there even if some explanations are not translated into English

The Colombo National Museum showcases Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich history and cultural heritage, housing priceless artifacts, royal regalia, ancient sculptures, manuscripts, and traditional art. Located in the heart of Colombo, this grand colonial-era building offers visitors a journey through the island‚Äôs past, from ancient kingdoms to colonial times. It is an essential stop for understanding Sri Lanka‚Äôs identity, traditions, and historical evolution. Also educational visit children who are 6+
Enjoyed viewing the various artefacts from clothing textiles to stones and agriculture. Great explanations with drawings to compliment.

column8: Must Visit for anybody who wish to understand the history of Sri Lanka
column11: Visited the Museum on 16th Oct, 2025. The museum was open for visitors, contrary to Google, which showed it was closed on Thursday. Tickets: I took a combined ticket for the Colombo Museum and the Natural Science Museum, which cost me 1500 LKR. Time Required: Given that the Museum closes at 6 pm, I had to rush a little; however, if you are a museum and history geek, you can easily spend 3-4 hours here, as the collection of artefacts of beautiful. Crowd: I visited on a weekday, so the crowd was less; however, the place is big enough to accommodate bigger crowds as well. Overall, a great experience. This building itself has a history of its own. Plus, there are many artefacts associated with Buddhism, so a good place to learn the history (political, cultural and economic) of the country.

column8: Exceeded my expectations, well worth a visit
column11: I visited this museum not expecting much. The building was pretty imposing ng and well looked after. The staff were all very friendly and welcoming. The ticket prices were competitive. The signage was excellent. Everything was arranged in chronological order from prehistory onwards. There was just enough information to read on each placard, and what it said was very clear. The prehistoric section was fascinating and had just enough artefacts to demonstrate points but not so many that it was overwhelming. There was a marvelous section on stupa architecture and Buddhist statues. The colonial furniture was much loved and looked after, which was a relief. I enjoyed the costume section showing the diversity of Sri Lankan culture. Overall this was a great way to spend three or four hours and get an overview of Sri Lankan history and archaeology. I highly recommend it.

column8: Got cheated at the ticket counter
column11: Count your money! Just got cheated. I paid with 5000 Rp for a 1500 Rp ticket. Received 2x1000, 1x500, 5x100. She counted that 3 times. But that is 500 Rp short. Bevause it is a lot of notes, many people will not notice this. But I counted it and noticed and told the lady. She said she did not have it and asked me to come back after the visit. Next local customer paid with a 500 Rp bill. So I expected to receive that. But no, she but it in the drawer and got another 1000 bill out of the drawer. In order words: she definitely had the exchange, and she did lie anout that. This was plain cheating. I told her, she just kept on smiling and saying sorry. Very clear that this was not accidentally, but on purpose. If the manage to do this 10 times a day, that is 5000 Rp. Note that a tea picker makes around 2000 Rp a day, a police officer around 3000 - 6000 Rp a day. So from their perspective this is a lot of money. So count the exchange.

column8: Are U in Colombo ? then a absolute must-visit destination!
column11: The Colombo National Museum is a captivating treasure trove of Sri Lanka's rich heritage! Home to over 10,000 artifacts, this remarkable institution showcases an incredible array of art, sculptures, monuments, and precious jewels that span from the ancient kings of Sri Lanka to the modern era of the 18th century.   One of the museum's most stunning highlights is the golden throne, crown, and sword of the last king of Sri Lanka, which were famously looted by the British during their rule but later returned to the island.  If you have a passion for history and archaeology, this is an absolute must-visit destination! Prepare to be amazed as you explore the stories and treasures that define Sri Lanka's vibrant past!

column8: The best place to get to know the long history of Sri Lanka
column11: A national museum with 250 years history. Numerous of galleries with different focuses. I love the ceramics and religious areas with fascinating exhibits. Unfortunately the temperature inside is humid and hot, it was hard to spend long time and study all the details. The government should preserve this national gem properly.

column8: Best way to start your Sri Lanka trip
column11: I think the Tohaku, Ky≈çhaku and Nara Museums are essential when foreigners come to Japan, so I visited Colombo National Museum without hesitation. After seeing word of mouth that there was no air conditioning and it was hot, I visited in Asaichi the day after arriving in Sri Lanka. He was refused credit cards and said to have no change, so he was first christened in this less functional country. The journey that followed was thought of, and it was the right one. The GF is roughly displayed by period and the upper floor by theme. One of my favorites is the bronze statue of Shiva Nataraja in Polonnaruwa in the 12th century. No less than the dancing Shiva I saw in India. A copy of Sigillian Lady is also a good preparatory note.
We visited as part of a city tour so only had half an hour. The building itself is interesting as is the last King‚Äôs throne. It is hot inside.
I like the building but it‚Äôs really dated and needs tremendous work and updating. It‚Äôs in a good location to worth a visit if you are visiting something else nearby. It has potential.

The museum is located in the city center and the entry fee is 1200 local currency.The museum is completely white and filled with the treasures paintings furnitures sculptures and the stories about the country.It is very special journey for me and I know the country better after visited the museum.I think this is somewhere you should not miss in Sri Lanka.
Worth a visit before you head inland to explore Kandy and other sites, lots of good info and explanations about the various dynasties and eras.

1200 rupees each which is very good value. No air con but fans in lots of places. Starts with each Kingdom of sri lanka on the bottom floor before doing textiles, art and other products of sri lanka on the top floor. Some exhibits are copies, others are originals. Still worth it bit as we had toured sri lanka by this point with a guide, we knew most of it

Beautiful place. Immaculate. Located in a busy part of city. Entrance fee ticket required - ONLY cash is preferred but they can accept card payment. Just push them. Inside, well organised. Only thing stopping you enjoy will be the heat and humidity. You  will end up rushing along this maze of museum.
It's a fascinating treasure trove and you can learn so much of Sri Lanka's rich cultural heritage. Most People are going there to study the sri lankan culture
The staff was not very helpful ! Refused us to go upstairs! Extremely hot in there! Some of the writing is so small and distanced. Appeared very dark in some place .

The Colombo National Museum is a magnificent building standing in its own grounds.  Built/opened in 1877 it has a hug Natural History collection.  The building is worth a look at just from the outside but the collections inside are terrific
Came as part of a city tour, plenty to see inside and displayed well with many information signs to read, enjoyed the outside and garden more, well-kept colonias style buildings.

The Colombo National Museum offers an enriching experience with its vast collection of Sri Lankan art, history, and culture. Highlights include ancient sculptures, royal artifacts, and traditional costumes. The museum‚Äôs informative displays provide a deep insight into the island‚Äôs heritage. A must-visit for history enthusiasts and traveler alike.

I don't have a lot of information, but my credit card was accepted because 20251 was a mess. The first floor is a museum, and the second floor is an art museum. The museum has paintings of the Sigiriya Lady that can be viewed by those who are not sure if they want to climb.

We visited this museum in December 2024 as part of our visit to Colombo. The building and it's grounds are the first thing that strike you as memorable. The exhibits themselves are decent and the museum is well curated and signposted. Worth a visit.

We went recently after seeing a lot of positive comments about the new improvements and we were pleasantly surprised of what we saw It was a very good experience. 15 halls ranging from pre historic era to the last kingdoms of sri lanka filled with artifacts and exhibits. Kids loved the space to roam around and I'm sure they will find it even more useful in future The staff can be a bit more friendly and engaging and I'm sure there is a lot of potential to do guided tours which we did not see available. The new Natural History enclosure was however bit of a buzzkill. The exhibits and the corridors were smelling of formalin and it was not pleasant for the kids

We did this tour along with a guided tour of the city. The museum has an excellent stock, including with returns of pieces that were in other countries, such as the Netherlands. You will go through a great journey that goes from the prehistoric period, through the colonization of the country and its former name Ceylon, agriculture, internal wars, influence of India and China, economy and currencies, crafts, among others. Worth a visit.
Claim and not crowded. There's lot to see specially about the Sri Lankan history. Kids loved the ocean themed division in the museum. Recommend  to make a visit.

Well-worth a couple of hours to stroll gently through this national museum. It‚Äôs laid out on two floors, with a chronological timeline running through the ground floor, and a thematic approach to different collections on the first floor. There are some real highlights - for me, the golden throne from Kandy, the multiple stone carvings, and the reproduction rock paintings from Sigiriya stood out. The historic building lends an authentic air too. Just be aware that there is no air conditioning (plenty of electric fans though) so time your visit accordingly if you can.

The National Museum of Colombo is located in Colombo 7, housing over 10,000 artefacts dating back 2,000 years. It is a treasure trove of history and heritage of Sri Lanka, a place you absolutely cannot miss when in Colombo! The museum boasts the Golden throne and crown of the last king of Sri Lanka, along with numerous artifacts showcasing the Buddhist history of the island. Come and explore the rich history and culture of Sri Lanka at the National Museum of Colombo‚Äîan experience you will never forget!

The National Museum, Colombo have been established on 1st of January 1877. Sir William Henry Gregory was the founder and was the British Governor of Ceylon at the time. The new architectural design of the museum has been done according to Italian architectural style.  The largest collection of cultural or significant objects are displayed and interprets and exhibits tangible and intangible heritage of Sri Lanka.

Very handsome museum, beautiful collection for the art lover...the only downside is the temperature in the rooms, the few fans keep, the intense heat in the museum unfortunately not outside..best dress as lightly as possible when visiting so whether you come (like me) soaked outside

The Colombo National Museum, situated in Colombo, Sri Lanka, is the country‚Äôs largest and oldest museum, established in 1877 by British governor Sir William Henry Gregory. This museum is a rich repository of Sri Lankan history, art, and culture, showcasing an extensive collection of artifacts that span millennia, offering deep insights into Sri Lanka‚Äôs heritage. The elegant white colonial-style building, set against a lush green garden, adds to its charm. The museum is meticulously maintained, with each exhibit clearly labeled for easy understanding. It‚Äôs truly one of the most impressive museums I‚Äôve visited. Tickets for foreign tourists are priced at 1500 LKR per person.

column11: The museum boasts an extensive collection of artifacts that cover various aspects of Sri Lanka‚Äôs history, from ancient civilizations to the colonial era. Some of the key highlights include
The museum established on 01 st January 1877.it founder was sir William Henry Gregory ,the British governor of Ceylon at the time

It is too warm inside and difficult to stay for a long time inside to see exabits. It's place with great artifacts and collections of amazing sri Lankan heritage. Unfortunately the place managed poorly and and available services are not upgraded for a while. There are some care takers are very professional and helpful but majority of them were lack of professional. Should be upgraded with new technologies and invest more to mark sri Lanka brand.

We moved from Kandy to Colombo and stopped by before visiting Geoffrey Bawa's studio. Due to the fact that it is a national museum, the admission fee was Rs. 1,200, but the only exhibition room with a cooler was the first introductory room, and all that was left was a fan. The wind is fixed towards the museum curators, so visitors have to endure the heat. Eventually it was too hot and I stopped taking pictures halfway through. There are also valuable materials from ancient sources and ruins, so I felt that it would be good if all the rooms were air-conditioned.

We visited as part of our tour of Sri Lanka We were told no photography which wasn't a problem. We were shown around by our guide which was useful as he added his own insights and views. The museum itself is an impressive building with pretty impressive grounds. We wandered in and it was pretty warm, there were fans set up to try and keep the building a bit cooler. There were a lot of different artifacts however there was a lot of seemingly repetitive and underwhelming items on display too. There seemed a lot of coins and the like as well as a whole section devoted to masonry with carvings and while there were probably people wanting to see them it seemed like an awful lot of similar items. There were collections various collections. Some more interesting than others. There was an animatronic display which was quite good too. This for me was very much a one visit location. Highlight was the Ice cream we had during our visit. as well as a Leopard photography display. We popped in and while it was a bit warm with no air con this was actually quite interesting.

There are many things to learn. In some places, there is sadness about the history of Sri Lanka. Sri Lanka is a country with an unimaginably beautiful culture. There are many religious monuments. Not happy with the ticket price.
A 2 story building with displays of the BC/AC ancient kingdoms of Sri Lanka, can‚Äôt see any modern history involving the Portuguese/Dutch/English occupation era
If you have not familiarized yourself with the history of Sri Lanka before your holiday, this is the place to get an overview. The museum is well organized and interesting.

Some really good displays of Sri Lanka's history, culture and environment, but let down by some poor lighting and patchy display information. The building itself is grand and you get to walk some of the verandahs between museum display rooms. Some of the artefacts recently returned from the Netherlands were particularly interesting. Don't miss the throne room.
Was very sad to see the tourist ticket price and local ticket prices and was so embarrassed. So many things are missing from our previous visits. Hope they are brought back.

Great museum that can last anywhere from thirty minutes to three hours, depending on interests. Majority of interesting exhibitions are in the first few rooms and it tapers off a lot afterwards, so if pressed for time focus on the first third or so. It is bigger than it looks.
Lots to see here - could easily spend 1-2 hours browsing the displays.  Separate toilets for tourists outside the main building.
A trip to this museum was part of a complimentary tour from our hotel. There was lots to see there but there were lots of staircases.

Struggled for time as we were part of a hotel arranged visit in which we had just 40 mins to whizz around. Place seemed to have a lot of interest- including a room dedicated to displaying items taken by the Dutch and returned years later. Another with a throne taken by the English and returned years later (theme emerging?)
A historical museum that allows you to get an idea of the life of this country with very ancient traditions. Various local finds and works of art...

Very informative and classied very nicely. You will need to spend at least 2- 3 hrs here to go through the entire mueseum. Categorised into 15 types ( weapons,  textiles, gems, architecture, paintings etc) Artifcats from Sri Lanka and around the world are displayed here. We paid in cash. Not sure about cards.

This is a fantastic museum. We went there on our way home to Melbourne, while we filled in time waiting for our flight. It was great as a way of better understanding what we had just experienced in Sri Lanka. It would also work as as a introduction to this wonderful country if you are spending time in Colombo at the start of a visit.

If you are visiting Colombo, the commercial capital of Sri Lanka, then a visit to the Colombo National Museum is a must. It's a fascinating treasure trove and you can learn so much of Sri Lanka's rich cultural heritage - my friends brought me here virtually as soon as I landed in Colombo. The highlight for me is seeing the majestic throne and crown of the King of Sri Lanka. The Museum is good value for money - if you are wanting to find out more about this island with deep insights into the history, heritage, culture of the peoples of Sri Lanka ,then I would highly recommend a visit here. You ought to spend at least half a day which I did. If you feel hungry, there is a food outlet outside the Museum serving Sri Lankan rice and curry and other food. I learnt so much by walking into this place - it brought alive Sri Lanka's rich history.

It was originally called the Colombo Museum and established in 1877 by the British Governor of Ceylon Sir William Henry Gregory. It holds many exhibits relating to Sri Lanka cultural and heritage. It is only 40 rupiahs for locals but foreigners pay more than ten times as much at 469 rupiahs.

This is not a modern museum, most of the exhibits, whilst interesting are displayed in a very "old school" way. If you are expecting technology and interactivity don't bother, but if you are seeking information about this remarkable country you'll get it in spades. This museum is next door to the Natural History Museum so you can save money by buying a combined ticket.
It was an enjoyable visit for us and the teens. Nicely laid out exhibits with lots of historical narrative posted in each room.

The museum is rather dark and damp to really enjoy the exhibits. Its not the most interesting for young kids. It would be great if some of the museum curators took an effort to explain exhibits to keep things a bit interesting. I dont think they have changed the exhibits since I was a kid!
Excellent museum highlighting the history of Sri Lanka and all visitors to the country should spend some time learning about the country. Worth an hour or so during ones time in Colombo

The National Museum has now been revamped and there is much more educational and recreational activities for the kids. several of the exhibits have been renovated and the area is very clean and neat. exhibits have light and sound action installed. there is a large art gallery area which houses old art and crafts items. A must visit for the kids!
Very nice place. Dignity and proud of üá±üá∞ . Really i like the place. We can learn abut srilanka history
Worth a visit. I'm not a great fan of museums but enjoyed a couple of hours here and saw some interesting exhibits.

Visited on 22/February/2020 Entry Fee applicable This place was one of the visit places in the Colombo tour itinerary and this place gives you a understanding of the history of Colombo, its establishment and so on. Displays are interesting and of interest for all those who love to know in-depth about the place of visit. If this makes you interested then do visit.
A large number of diverse artefacts, from many eras, all labelled. Sculpture, paintings, fabric, jewellery, pottery, currency, etc The building itself is beautiful.

Easy to find your way through the exhibition as there are clear signposts throughout guiding you to each gallery. The exhibits and information provided give a good insight into centuries of Sri Lankan history. We visited after a 2 week trip around Sri Lanka and our visit helped to cement and make sense of what we had seen on our trip. Worth visiting.

A huge collection of very nice artefacts - lots of  statues, paintings, bric-a-brac, etc.  Good explanations of all material displayed. Some the paintings on cloth are immense. Very imposing building.  Everything kept in very good condition in a neat and clean environment.  Definitely a pride of Sri Lanka! Wear comfortable walking shoes. The canteen adjacent is a bit grubby.  I suspect used by all museum staff.

We weren‚Äôt blown away, but it‚Äôs a nice museum. It is located in a nice, old House built 150 years ago by the British. You can see the items from the prehistoric age, the iron a age, lots of Buddha skulptures, old paintings, stone sculptures, Ganesha sculptures, old clothes and jewelrys, agriculture from the past and coins for example. We missed exhibits from the last 100 years. But overall it was interesting. No air-condition is available, only fans.

Spent all morning wandering around the very informative museum. It was good to revisit information about the places we‚Äôd visited during our three week stay. Good value for money with the combined ticket for the Natural History museum too.

Especially if you want to escape the hot Colombo centre this is a very good option. It is not that big but equipped with many interesting things to see and to learn about Sri Lanka. Take your time and enjoy many different aspects of art, culture, religion, handcraft, historical cities, excavations... and many other things :)

It was nice to spend an hour here all very informative on life in Sri Lanka a very well  laid out display as we was on a coach tour it was not long enough to appreciate all this museum had to offer but what we did see would make us come back to have a longer stay.

The museum has 15 major displays over two floors of a series of interconnected colonial buildings.  We got through the lot but took a break at the cafe next door - you can exit and return at no extra charge. The toilets are located there, too. We enjoyed the visit - the coins and early trade discussions were particularly interesting. The throne was impressive, too. It seemed odd that there was not more attention given to the colonial period. Yes, it was mentioned in places but there was not a specific section. As others have  mentioned, it is not air conditioned and the odd tourist group distrupted the otherwise peace and quiet. It is certainly a grand building from the outside and it is good that it has been retained
Wonderful exhibits and hopefully one day SL with have the resources available to keep them in pristine condition for future generations. A great place to spend a couple of hours.

We came to the National Museum towards the end of the day, in hopes of finding out a little more about the country and to see some of the artifacts illustrating the history. The space itself is vast and quite old. It is a cavernous series of connected rooms cooled only by standing fans, filled with objects and art kept in old cases with glass panes. We saw lovely original pieces and some reproductions with the originals held by the colonist countries still (very sad). The larger general descriptions were well written and helpful, but the objects themselves were only labeled with no identifying facts, which I found frustrating. There were also a number of displays that were dated (lifesized dioramas of jungle scenes with sound effects, etc...). We walked and walked (quickly to get upstairs before the 4pm closing time for upper floors) and were stuck behind a large tour group part of the time, which was very frustrating as they stood in front of important pieces, not moving to let others in to see. I think this is an important landmark and tourist destination that would benefit with major updates to the displays. There is also a sense that the objects are not benefiting from the spaces they are kept in (wondering how they are damaged by the heat/light/etc...). If you have time and the entrance fee, it is worth a visit.

We visited this museum as part of a shore excursion from our cruise ship that was docked in Colombo. This is a large extensive historical museum housed in beautiful colonial buildings that has quite extensive collections in it.  Most of displays did have English explanations.  It also has a film at the entrance of the museum that covers some of the history of Sri Lanka. This room has air conditioning and seating. Since this is a colonial building it does not have air conditioning but I found the temperature was comfortable due to cross breezes.  There are no toilets in the museum building itself.  However, there are western toilets in the gift shop building and in annex to the main toilet building located outside of the main museum buildings. The gift shop is quite extensive with lots of various types of souvenirs in it.  I would recommend that you spend 2 to 3 hours to fully enjoy this museum.

This very large colonial building houses thousands of archaeological articles from Pre Common Era to the Agricultural Era. They are well labeled in three languages with understandable descriptions of activities and uses of the items. It lacks benches and seating areas particularly for the demographic that generally visits museums of this nature. There is no reference in this museum of the modern historical, political, financial or economic progress of Sri Lanka. If you have not seen the ancient city triangle of Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa and Kandy, this museum would satisfy your thirst for knowledge of the past 30,000 years in Sri Lanka We were impressed with how extensive the collection is and how professionally it is presented.

I enjoy visiting national museums when I am travelling because I believe this always widens your perspective of wherever you are and takes you beyond just ‚Äûsightseeing‚Äù. Shame that‚Äôs just not the case with this museum :-( It‚Äôs quite disappointing and (sorry to say) boring in fact, given the rich history of Sri Lanka. The tickets are 1000LKR for an adult and if you come too close to closing time you are allowed entrance only to the ground floor. Fair enough, but why charge full price for that? There is no A/C so if you do choose to go, don‚Äôt do it midday... Better yet - skip the place altogether and buy yourself a good book on the history of Sri Lanka.

We were fascinated by the extensive and breathtaking artifacts displayed in the National Museum. A large colonial style building houses the national collection of Sri Lankan history. Cannot say enough about the quality and the layout of the museum. It was beautiful. The whole of Sri Lankan history (and prehistoric history as well) was presented over many floors and large galleries. We were blown away with the artistry and evolution of the island. A great first stop in Colombo and a must see location.

I‚Äôve always thought you should visit a county‚Äôs National Museum if you get the chance. It‚Äôs worth it. A beautiful building depicting the history of Sri Lanka. Stroll through the rooms at your own pace and try to take it all in. Lots and lots to see and learn. It is quite warm in the museum as there is no ac. Not a big deal. Bring some water. You‚Äôll be glad you went.

We visited the national museum in January and were very impressed, not only by the exhibitions which were carefully presented, but also by the beautiful building and the lovely Sri Lankan cafeteria. A must do for those who appreciate Sri Lankan history and culture.

This was a genuinely pleasant surprise - a beautiful 19th century building, overflowing with treasures from Sri Lanka's past from prehistory to the present day. Our kids (4 and 7) loved wandering the halls looking at the exhibits. (Don't forget to pop into the park next door afterwards to rest your weary legs and watch the world / squirrels / parkeets / fruitbats go by!)

This is a great museum of the history of the country, with a great collection of artifacts and replicas. The preserved skeletons and the art were my favourite parts. Some of the dioramas need to be touched up but overall a great collection well worth the visit. Compared with some of the museums we have visited, 1000 rupees for admission is cheap, considering that to do this museum justice you will need to spend the whole day here.

When I needed a museum to visit, I was so happy to standing in the lobby of this museum.  It gives an excellent history of the creation of Sri Lanka.    I‚Äôve never realized that Sri Lanka was a country till I went here.  You should attend.

A traditional style of national museum starting with man‚Äôs early history up to recent time. It was started by a British colonial. Some interesting exhibits, one which I enjoyed was seeing the colonial period clothing of the Burghers. Worth a visit, but it was a hot day, and there aren‚Äôt A/C or good fans. The museum store has many handcrafted items with good prices.

This is great for history students and who have passion to study history of places. The museum building itself is great but the lighting is not very effective but I enjoyed seeing so many new items showcasing history dating back to centuries.

It was our first time in Sri Lanka and I thought it would be a good way to get to know this little but complex country before we left Colombo to explore. The museum is small and well organized, and although the expositions are not new and do not count with technological improvements, the pieces in the expositions are great and worth the visit. Every information is translated to English in the boards with short and clear explanations. We learned a lot by this visit, specially about the different eras of the mighty empires of Anuradhapura, Pollonaruwa and the more recent Kandean period. Worth the visit ! Take 2-3 hours to explore the museum without haste.

The museum has artifacts that are dated and old yet well preserved.  There are descriptions written that make it easy to understand the artifacts.  It's amazing to know how old the history of Sri Lanka is. It was extremely humid with fans placed at some places. Either there should be AC or fans as our can get pretty claustrophobic.

This museum is a stunning complex and has a very selective and profound art collection. While a few fools don't like paying an absurdly cheap price of $5 entry even though their own countries charge so much more for museums, you shouldn't equally deceive yourself. Some true masterpieces here, a great historical and cultural understating of this island. Easily five stars!

After being sick of paying lots extra for Sri Lanka tourist sights, I would have at least expected a museum in the capital to be free, or cheap. 1000Lkr for foreigners and basically nothing for locals. Didnt bother going in as I refuse to pay for this stuff that should be the same price for all. Or at least not 10 times more expensive.
Well guided from the begining to the end by the symbols. But staff is not supported by explaining the special areas. So the staff in the place needs to more proactive than this.
Its located in the heart of the city and has a detailed information about the heritage and history of the lankan island.

I'm still trying to understand how our tour only allowed us one hour at this museum to view eleven galleries of national treasures. We managed to view five galleries and enjoyed the experience albeit disappointed that we could not visit the remainder. The displays could be better curated but that's just my viewpoint; there is substantial information on many of the exhibits while very brief on others. The galleries visited display artefacts belonging to the Pre and Proto Historic, Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Kandy and Transitional periods. From among all these treasures I selected the Goddess Tara, the Elephant Lamp, Siva-Nataraja, the Royal Seat and the stunning Samadhi Buddha statue under the Makara Arch as my favourite displays. The museum is housed in an impressive building dating to 1877 and founded by Sir William Henry Gregory, the British Governor at the time. A statue in his honour stands in the lawned area fronting the main entrance with notation, "erected by the inhabitants of this island to commemorate the many benefits conferred by him upon the colony during his administration of the government 1872 - 1877". This museum is a fitting legacy

A real throwback to the past, in all senses.  Has not been done up for ages and whilst there are some nice artefacts they are poorly displayed with little information.  The whole place is dreary and dim.   Two floors but no lift and although they say they close the second floor at 4pm it was closed by 3.15 today and we couldn‚Äôt go up. It is in a complex of government buildings and there are only limited ways out of the compound so I had to walk a long way round to get to a road. I am mildly disabled and need to sit from time to time but no chairs except for the room attendants.  No free info. A small printed guide  was 10 rupees but we didn‚Äôt have small enough change so couldn‚Äôt have one. Wouldn‚Äôt go back
We did not visit the Museum but a look at this building is not to be missed on a visit to Colombo.  It is a magnificent example of British colonial architecture set in lovely expansive lawns.

I would strongly urge all visitors to Sri Lanka to visit this museum. It offers a comprehensive history of the country, it's traditions and it's people from prehistoric times through to the present day. We visited at the beginning of our tour and I felt it gave us a better perspective and understanding of the country before we visited other sites.

The National Museum of Colombo was 100% worth it! Our entire visit allows us to understand the entire story of Sri Lanka. It showcases the culture of the country, along with documents and antiques displayed inside. The establishment was very clean too.
There are lots of artifacts here and archaeological specimens. I was hoping for more information on the civil war but the museum is impressive enough as is. The section on masks is very interesting.

We did this at the end of a two week trip around Sri Lanka and it puts all that we saw into perspective and joined the dots for us (where we were confused about who ruled when and where)! Many examples of the country's cultural achievements as well as it's historical roots. Definitely wotrth visiting for a couple of hours or so.

It will surprise and disappoint those who believe Hinduism and Buddhism are dissimilar or mutually antagonistic. The museum has relatively less focus on Sri Lanka's Islamic heritage. I had gone to see the trilingual (Chinese, Tamil, Persian) stone inscription about the voyage of the great Chinese explorer Zheng He (1371-1433), who visited both Sri Lanka and India. If you are a visitor to Colombo, don't miss it.

This museum was first opened as the Colombo Museum on 1 January 1877 to display the cultural and natural heritage of Ceylon. Later it was given the status of Colombo National Museum (CNM) and is the largest museum in Sri Lanka. It is a huge white-painted Italianate style building within a quiet parkland environment. It is open every day except for Public Holidays, from 9am to 6pm. Entry prices are R60 for locals and R1,000 for foreigners but discounted prices of R100 and R1,200 allow you to visit both the CNM and the National Museum of Natural History. The CNM has 2 floors. The ground floor records the ancient history of Sri Lanka, in successive galleries from Pre-History through the periods of Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Transitional and  Kandy. The top floor is devoted to paintings, textiles, pottery, coins, banners, art & craft, armaments and agriculture. The displays are well laid out and presented with substantial information in 3 languages. However it is very hot inside this museum and not all the fans were working when we were there. It was very tiring and there was nowhere to sit and rest on the lengthy trip around the galleries. If both of these issues could be addressed, this museum may attract more visitors.

Colombo museum is agood place to visit toget aknowledge of srilankan culture. We visited different part of it and some things of the anciant times are amazing So  I advice to every tourist to visit this place.

The Colombo National Museum can be found opposite Viharamahadevi Park and you will need a couple of hours to look around both buildings. The main part of the museum is a grand colonial style building which was built in 1877. There is an entrance fee and you get shown into the first building which is all about nature and how things grow etc in Sri Lanka. There is also a large dinosaur skeleton to see at the end of this building before you are shown to the main building. This building is full of artefacts such as art, weapons, furniture , paintings etc. to see and plenty of staff about to answer your questions , if you have any. There is a caf√© and gift shop in the grounds and the gardens are which are well kept by the staff. An enjoyable visit which takes about a couple of hours and gets one away from the humidity and heat!
The Best out of many museums in Lanka. Extended collection of art, textile, arms, money etc. Helpful staff! By the way, the building was found in 1877 and it is still in a perfect condition.

There was definitely more staff than visitors on the day we stopped by for a few hour tour of the museum. The building itself is neat, so are its surroundings, but safe for a few interesting statues and the throne from Kandy, it's not an essential stop on your Colombo trip. No A/C, and a very outdated exhibition welcome you.

this is the biggest museum in srilanka. its very colonial style building and lot of things to see.facilities for the tourists are not so enough. but we can see different kind of centuries with different cultures antiques.they renovate when i am last time and its not so bad. must visit place in colombo and its also not so big. within two hours you can see all the things. interesting place
Nice visit in the afternoon when it's very hot. It takes around 90 min,2 floors, then there is a coffee shop
Unless you are an anthropologist or an archeologist skip , very dated.  I left after 15 min.  The staff took 20 min to start the video. Go to the  Mt. Livonia Hotel instead for tea.

Founded in 1877 is the national museum which houses artifacts spanning the history of Sri Lanka.  The two story structure is houses a rich history of covering a period of 2500 years and includes important collections including the throne and crown of the Kandyan monarchs.  There are three main sections including natural science, cultural and a library.  Signs direct you through the maze of rooms which are cooled with large fans--ther is no air conditioning.  Guards sit at the entrance of many of the rooms.  The museum opens at 9am and closes at 6pm.  There is a small fee for entrance.  Next door is the Laksala Government Gift Shop which houses a huge variety of Sea Lankan art work and souvenirs and the prices are very reasonable.  Plan on spending about 1-2 hours if you visit all of the rooms.

The museum is accomodated in a great white house. They have plenty of rooms with a lot of differented topics. It's specially nice if you bring a visit after you made your roundtrip. You will recognize more. Definitely worth a visit!

Housed in a beautiful old mansion, the Colombo National Museum is definitely worth a visit. Each room has a different collection of artifacts, beginning with pre-history and ending with a farming/agricultural models. These two are probably the least interesting, although the models are quite lifelike compared to some we've encountered in other countries. The weapons, clothing and costumes, jewellery, pottery, ivory, stone statuary and a fine collection of stone urinals kept us engaged for some time. The chitty system at the entrance was in full sub-continental swing. It is non-air conditioned, but is not too hot due to high ceilings, fans and open doors.

I loved my afternoon at the National Museum. There was a tremendous amount of information, and everything was beautifully displayed. I especially enjoyed the bronzes and sculptures from the 8th and 9th centuries and the traditional Sri Lankan masks. I have to say that it‚Äôs pretty hot though - there are fans but not air conditioning. Take plenty of water!

We were in two minds as to whether the museum was worth the effort, however, the building alone is well worth seeing. Inside, much of it has been recently renovated and the historical exhibits are extremely well displayed with excellent English explanations. However, if you are interested in the Colonial era, there really is very little and you would be forgiven for thinking that the Europeans ever had anything to do in Sri Lanka not withstanding that the idea of building the museum was by one of the British governors and the building itself is classic colonial style on a grand scale. The exhibits concentrate very much on Sri Lanka‚Äòs pre history and the history of the kings, folk lore etc. That said, you would be missing out on a well planned lay out and an informative couple of hours if you chose to miss it.

Once you get past the pre-historic displays (skip) and past the hordes of school children, there is some good stuff here, but it is limited in my view. Enjoy the Buddha statues and related stuff, but it goes downhill from there in my view. Yes it is the national museum in the capital so it has an encyclopedic collection, but unless you want to see every old farm tool in often not very well lit displays, you can really speed up. I was time-limited anyway, but seriously an hour was enough for a visit. Yes it is an old building, so lacks a/c, and route is one way to upstairs then out on side of building. The price had gone up from guidebook 600r. to 1000r. and as it is a national museum that sounds OK, as likely all tourists will go. However the museum in Kandy is much better value in my view- a much more compact and curated collection. The highlights of this one really, and very presented and lit, despite guidebook comments that it was like Colombo, dusty, unlit etc.

Unfortunately, when I arrived around 5 pm, this place was closed but I liked the souvenir shop which was open. The architecture of the place is really nice....Next time I will try to go early to be able to enter the museum.

Well first off the building has no AC.   Dress appropriately.    The building contains statues, art, coins, and facades from centuries ago. You will be immersed in what it meant to in the area long ago. The Natural History Museum is behind the main building and in my opinion not worth the entry fee and could be overlooked. You will pay more than the locals but still the price was not awful.    My biggest fear in seeing all the antiquities was that the unmitigated heat and humidity will denature the quality of the artifacts contained inside the museum.

We did a city tour by tuktuk and this was one of the places the driver took us to. It was a really interesting visit with lots of facts throughout the ages of Sri Lanka including masks, clothing, jewellery, coins, artefacts and the different countries to have ruled. Well worth a visit to find out the background and history of Sri Lanka.

Good choice to visit this Museum, nice colonial building, but inside is hot hot and hot, exponates are chaotic collected on many places, many "Educative" models are without reality. Bookstore is poor and not interesting, cofee/tee is far and by the exit is the "restoran" for local people only with higher prices for foregners. Totaly full joke is the Museum of Nature, only the whale skeleton is remarcable, other exhibitions (except geology) are poor full of mistakes and Mme Tussaud Animals... No more frineds.

The museum is a lovely old building with a nice coffee shop out back to relax after walking round the mueseum. There are plently of things on display. Im giving it an average overall because there is zero effort from the museum to explain anything or try create an educational experience to learn about the country and history. Everything is there to see, and there is loads of it. Its just my opinion is should be presented to visitors better.

This is a beautiful place. The museum has a good collection of historical artifacts, however without a good guided tour, sometimes it is difficult to understand much.  We tried asking for an official guide of the museum, but the lady was not much keen on telling us about the things on display. Basically she only walked with us through the halls.

The National Museum has a great collection of historical items, well displayed in a purpose-built colonial building. Exhibits are well described in Sinhala, Tamil and English. There is an excellent cafe.
Interesting old colonial type building with lots of artefacts and informative displays depicting Sri Lankan history and culture. It won‚Äôt take long to take this in, maybe just as well, no a/c

With a spare afternoon we visited the museum and spent an interesting and worthwhile time. The building itself is worth the visit but the exhibits cover everything from early history, religious artifacts and art, Royal regalia costumes, jewelry , China glassware and all manner of fascinating items from the country‚Äôs historical and colonial past. A great museum shop and cafe for a midway refreshment.

Well signposted once inside. Foreigners pay 1000 rupees for visit. Exhibits are on two floors. No lift. My elderly mother struggled to go upstairs . Many chairs scattered around so that she could sit when tired. Lots of Buddhist items from Pollannaruwa  and Anuradhapura bronze statues stone items paintings . Museum Not air conditioned and toilet facilities in another block. Small basic canteen serving rice and curries drinks and snacks
You can enjoy new information yet it feels more like a school field trip. Its a Rich culture and a must see

Beautiful museum with good layout of displays-  in time order then upstairs is grouped by artefact type. You can get a ticket for just this museum or also the natural history one, which is more like a school biology level.

I'm not one who generally enjoys museums but this one I did.The buildings themselves were beautiful and well maintained.Each room held a different collection so you walked from one to another not getting bored.Plenty to see and more to see outside.Worth the visit just to see the buildings

This museum has no air conditioning, only fans.  It was quite hot.  Some of the exhibits seemed a little tired and needed refurbishing.  There are no restrooms in the museum.  The ones on the grounds are only squat toilets.  There were some nice artifacts in here, and also some nice paintings.  Not the best museum I was ever in.

Very elegant building with 15 rooms displaying history and development of Sri Lanka. Good signage and information. Only disappointment was lack of 19th and 20th century information unless I missed it.

I wasn't sure if I should invest time there because of the mixed reviews here. I really enjoyed the exhibits, the setup and the explanations. Most museums in Asia are not as informative or well done as people from the West are used to. So, the exhibits and everything needs to be seen in context. Overall, it a very good museum that gives an insight into the history, culture, tradition and people of Sri Lanka. As this was my first visit in the country and since I know India very well as I live(d) there for years, I truly appreciated the museum and recommend it.

Intetesting insight into Sri Lankan history and culture. Lovely building and some interesting well layed out exhibits. Expensive as all tourist attractions are in Sri Lanka to foreigners but worth a visit. Colombo is not filled with attractions so this rates highly.

If you have a full itinerary, I would probably skip this museum. Cost was $8 and I didn't think it was worth it. I spent about an hour inside. The artifacts and paintings were beautiful. It provided a nice history of Sri Lanka but I was really bored for most of it. If you have lots of time in Colombo and LOVE history then you will enjoy it. If you are limited on time, definitely skip it. Bring your camera because the outside is beautiful.

This museum is very comprehensive in giving a good insight into the development of Sri Lanka. There are a wide range of exhibits with generally good labelling in English. We recommend spending at least 30 minutes each in the first two rooms as this sets the scene for the rest of the exhibition.
Well worth a visit and if you have a few hours take your time. There are a huge amount of exhibits but nothing from the 20th century

This is a large museum on two floors with excellent pieces of ancient and more modern items too. The labelling is generally very good if you speak English. The museum has none of the interactive displays that a modern museum would have but it is still very interesting and well worth a visit. The authorities need to invest in better facilities.the toilets are appalling and the cafe is poor. Considering the high standard of cafes nearby such as The Commons, I was disappointed. As an introduction to the culture of the country I think a visit to this place is essential. It is open every day except public holidays. If you buy a ticket you are allowed to exit and return on the same day. Highlights are the prehistoric tombs, carved stone statues and columns, ceremonial throne and weapons, textiles.

The Colombo National Museum details Sri Lanka ancient past and it's colonial periods - although it seeks to create the impression was the island was uninhabited before the arrival of the Sinhalese. It is well worth visiting the museum as a prelude to visiting the ancient cities of Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa .
This was beautifully set up and well worth a trip.  English translation very good and exhibits very interesting.

We have just spent 15 days touring the island and we found the collection here very good examples of what we have seem in the ancient cities themselves, in some cases even better. The layout is very well done and it certainly gave us a better understanding of the Sri Lankan periods and cultures and other influences.

Amazing. Collection. We did a lot of touring around Sri Lanka and saw plenty of ancient, architectural and archaeological sites. So we went here on our last day in Sri Lanka to help tie everything together. However, people say it's a great intro cultural  collection to the country. But also a nice farewell.

If you are interested in the history of Sri Lanka, you should go the this museum. It will provide you with a brief introduction on the country and her history. Note: the recent history is not really added to the collection (yet). Beautiful building and gardens around the museum. Note: entrance ticket: price seems to be flexible.
Large museum in impressive old building with nice grounds. Displays were well laid out and sign posted to walk around in order. Was hot inside the museum and the toilets were outside.

It is well kept and clean. Fee for the entry of a visitor from SAARC country is SLR 1000. There is no entry from the front road of the building. The car or bus is parked near the back of the museum, and one has to walk to the front to purchase a ticket. There are many sections but no toilet once you are inside or have purchased the ticket for entry. One has to go back near the parking. It has a good display and some recent history of the country. Even if some parts of Srilanka like Sigriya, you have not been to go can be glimpsed in some room. I saw paintings displayed on the wall there. The museum has many things written below the display and will need time to read, so two hours are required to enjoy it fully. It is appreciated that photographs can be taken. It is allowed.

Visited this place when I had a few hours to kill in Colombo. The entrance fee of Rs.1000 was too high in my opinion. The collections of the museum vary from very average to somewhat interesting.  Some more contemporary displays would have been nice. Foreigners: beware of the cafeteria.  I asked for a chocolate drink that I was told cost Rs.150.  Paid 500, but was shortchanged by 100.  I had to ask for this extra money. Moreover, upon finishing the drink, I noticed it was labelled 50, not 150.  Again, I had to request that I be given an extra 100 back that I was duly owed.  The two apologies from the cashier were very insincere, and it is therefore regrettable to experience the extent to which they went to try and rip me, a foreign tourist, off.  This is from a government owned museum.  Shameful. Upon leaving, I was asked to complete a survey.  Apparently staff members within the exhibitions are meant to chat to you about their various displays, however, I can only say this was the case with 1 single staff member! Nevertheless, the woman conducting the survey was very friendly, and provided me with very detailed instructions on taking the bus back to my hotel.  This was a very positive note to end on.

The museum is in an impressive old building and grounds. Inexpensive entry. Linear walk round well presented displays, with some interesting items. Well worth a visit if you arrive in Colombo and before you head out to explore the country and its historical sites. Was quiet when we toured.

A lovely day out, I paid $1,000 rupees to get in and my Sri Lankan husband paid about .60 rupees! There is some amazing things to look at 15 rooms in total, with artefacts just laying around everywhere. I was surprised to see such old artefacts just there in front of me, not behind protective glass. I learnt a lot about Sri Lanka‚Äôs history, even about old toilets.

Rs. 1000 per person will get you into this stately building and its well organized halls containing a vast collection of artifacts from ancient and colonial history. Unfortunately, it does stop there, and you do not learn about contemporary Sri Lanka. Thankfully, the collection is neatly partitioned thematically and chronologically, so that you can pick and choose--and choose you must!

Skip the natural history museum even though you have to get a combined ticket for 1,200 - it‚Äôs just basic earth history. The Sri Lankan history exhibits in the other building are disorganised but go on for longer than you‚Äôd expect and cover many different things with a few gems to be found (the mask exhibit is particularly good). The counter couldn‚Äôt give me change for 1,500 and I had to go back later for it, poor form at these prices, but there‚Äôs not much else to see in Colombo.

The Colombo National Museum is a treasure worth visiting. Allow enough time if you like history. 2 stories of treasures about Sri Lanka. The National Museum houses 4,000 palm leaf manuscripts, coins, guns and weapons, art and the history of early man. Worth a visit.
Plenty of historical artefacts to see aswell as beautiful sculptures. The museum has a lot of view and read about.

This was only our 2nd day in Sri Lanka and before we made our way up country it was a chance to understand the early history of Sri Lanka and how some of the places we planned to visit fit together. It was housed in lovely building and was set out with 15 different rooms. It was easy to understand the different periods Sri Lanka has gone through and as we were going to Anuradhapura the next day gave us some ideas what to see including  the early method of irrigation by building 3 tanks. We spent over 2 hours and really enjoyed it. It cost LKR 1000 for an adult.

This is the best place to learn the Sri Lankan history. There are lot of things to read and see over here. I really liked the new room dedicated to the Silk Road and the Chinese Shi dynasty who were originally Sri Lankan who went to to China and settled in. The tour takes around 3 hours and parking is available.

A good 1.5 hour is useful for this very rich museum presenting collections form the whole island, with paintings, scuptures and many photos of places to be later visited. entrance 1000 rupees, no photo fee.

Not only is the building spectacular, but the museum has an amazing selection of Sri Lankan historic artifacts and artwork.  It is not airconditioned but many fans help in hot weather.  There are a couple of coffee shops, one in front of the tourist shop which is also worth a visit.

Designed and built as a museum and expanded several times to house the growing collections of antiquities this place is a must visit.  The building itself is a great example of colonial Dutch architecture and each of the expansions carries the same feel. The collection is vast and is well displayed and curated. Well worth the 1000 LKR entry.
This place acts as a gateway to Sri Lanka's history. There are lot of artifacts to see, all divided by sections. Must visit!
Talks about Buddhism, early kingdoms in Sri Lanka, and exhibits from and influences from South Indian civilizations. Go only if you are into history

Visited here recently on a tour of the country. The place is filled with interesting artifacts and was pleasantly cool which was a bonus given the temperatures outside. Allow about an hour for your visit.

The museum is in a beautiful building that has recently been renovated. The layout is very old fashioned - you can not just go to the rooms that interest you, you need to follow the trail IKEA style - but unlike IKEA there are no short cuts! You are going to see prehistoric rock formations whether you want to or not. The entry fee for tourists is high and does not represent value of any kind. As other reviewers have said - the written descriptions either don't exist are so long winded and are so poorly written you give up the will to live. The one interactive display (of paddy field irrigation) was not working. There is no air conditioning only fans - pointed firmly at the exhibition staff - so the whole experience is quite draining. The textiles area has beautiful embroideries and historic costumes - delightful if under explained. We would have enjoyed looking at the crafts and jewelry more thoroughly (they have a fabulous collection) but these were housed in one of the later rooms and by that stage we were too exhausted. At the end of your visit you are rewarded with 2 restaurants. One is very much for the locals the other for 'pigeons' - this is what tourists are called.
Very informative and now beautifully presented . Try to spend at least half day to walk through slowly,
This museum is full of well presented treasures offering an interesting insight to Sri Lanka‚Äôs history. A wonderful building kept in excellent condition Well worth a visit

The museum is very interesting and has lots of curious artifacts from Sri Lanka. I only wish there was more information on the pieces , like where they actually came from in Sri Lanka and what period they belong to. The building is also fantastic, definitely worth visiting!
Much more than what we expected - many galleries with interesting exhibits. Had to rush through as it closed at 5pm.

Worth a visit, but allow sufficient time to meander through the two stories of galleries.  It's hot, cooled only by odd fans turned towards the attendants' chairs, but the displays are fascinating. Chairs for the hot and weary would be a great improvement!

It's a large museum, so needs time and energy. You have to go there if you have gone to SL for more than the beaches and the food! We noted some very interesting displays,and also, of course, one or two dreary sections
very knowledgeable  place , special for all school children .. in this place we can learn about sri lankan culture

As is the case for many tourist destinations in Sri Lanka, tourists get charged an extortionate fee compared to locals (1000lkr V 100). I personally didn't think it was worth it; considering you can go to far more high tech and interactive museums for free in the UK. I did learn some things especially about Sri Lankan history, but there was often just far too much writing that you just gave up. Wouldn't recommend for children as is not interactive at all. Definitely not a must do.
Well worth a visit. We spent 3 hours there. So much to see on several floors.Excellent. It was very informative and enlightening.
Impressive and beautiful collection, definitely worth the price and visit. Bought a joint ticket with which you can visit the museum of natural history as well.

I love visiting museums around the world and maybe this is what I am comparing to so have traveled to over 70 counties around the world so I usually will go to the national museum This unfortunately was one that actually is done quite poor and not fun at all It was not done well at all , not informative the collection was not displayed well , not very informative not interesting at all in my opinion So my verdict is there is so much more to do in this beautiful country like going to Galle . kandy , visiting tea plantations

For those who don't know much about this South Asian country, the Museum is a great place to start getting acquainted with its people, history, and culture and to be awed by its enchanting arts and crafts.  The only drawback, especially for seniors, is the absence of lifts.  An introductory leaflet would be useful, too.
This is the place you can learn & see the proud history of Srilanka. When you visit Srilanka, this a place you must visit. Spending few hours is very much useful and enjoyable.
Was very impressed with the range of exhibits and the quality of the information at the museum. Would recommend at the beginning or end of a Sri lankian trip. The museum building itself is beautiful.
A lot of things to see especially about the history of Sri Lanka and the different kingdoms that existed. Gives a good appreciation for the rich heritage of the country.
History of Sri Lanka from ancient times. Each hall presents different periods. Many exhibits and descriptions. All descriptions are in English. Museum is on 2 floors. Entrance ticket is 1200 rupees.

You must experience this place. Under funded third world and run down. Some of the artifacts are amazing and ancient. The museum consists of multiple buildings surrounded by old trees. Some displays have never been updated and some children would find the paintings and displays laughable. Other buildings house some absolutely ancient artifacts. Admission is minimal and photography is an extra 40cents. Well worth a visit to see early history. In the street on the South side are framed paintings of local artists if you want some original work to take home. On display 10am till 4pm. Check the pencil figure on the back for the local price.

Probably not a day out for the kids but there is certainly enough of interest in the museum to keep everyone entertained for an hour or two. It's right in the centre of the city also, so you can easily plan to visit on the way somewhere else

Lovely n well maintained place. Not a big place to visit but worth a visit. The entrance fee for a foreigner is exhorbitent. You may stay preper to take a look from outside. You can challenge photography capability ... Worth to visit as family.

I went to this museum today and was immediately impressed by the presentation of exhibits in this huge old building of many beautiful objects from Sri Lanka history.  Most foreigners visiting here will learn something and the locals I met while walking through the exhibits were also impressed. Buddhists and art lovers are well catered for but If you are part of the instant information generation [google style] you may find it a bit of an effort so best you stay away. If you can appreciate a culture through it's artifacts and visual history then this museum will not disappoint you. I would like to say to Tripadvisor that the questions at the end of this review[ and others I have filled out lately] do not make sense - surely you have data that enables you to ask more relevant questions?

As museums go in developing countries this is a great one! Lots of exhibits with English explanations. Some lovely dioramas on the upper floor. Cool and roomy. And a great shop and cafe outside with decent toilets. The gifts in the shop were very reasonably priced.i bought a sunhat for ¬£2!

The collection includes murals from Sigiriya, traditional masks, a coin collection, and Buddhist artifacts.  Surprisingly the museum is not climate controlled.  Check with your hotel when they are open, the hours posted are well shall we say aspirational.  Worth an hour or two to visit.
We were just outside of the museum. Looks nice, didn't had enough time to visit it unfortunately. The security was good. If it rains maybe come here?

It is a very well stocked museum displaying various artifacts of preindependece history of SriLanka. It takes us through various ages, kingdoms and civilisations. It is very good start point for exploring SriLanka. Based on the information gathered here, one should select and then visit original places in different parts of SriLanka.

Its a beautiful building, after a very long renovation, its open to public. Unfortunately some of the artifacts were stolen few years ago and the culprits were never found. There isn't much to see. Only attraction is the Throne of the last Kandian king. Many other very valuable artifacts were removed by the British during their colonial rule. Probably Britain has more of archilogical artifacts than all Sri Lankan museums...

Having visited this city many times. I now ( with my husband) visited this museum. It was great to find out what happened up until Sri Lanka becme a British Colony, but then ver little. I would have wanted to know a lot more about the what happened then!!!!
There's a big improvement after the renovation. This building is magnificent and deserves the money spent to maintain and restore it to its lost grandeur! Well worth a visit.
Quite well maintained! Sections well organised. Gets a bit warm suggest carrying water bottles & a hand fan.
For those interested in museums, this one offers quite an array of historic and cultural displays. Just a word for the wise, it's not air conditioned but has some fans in place!

The National Museum building could use a little TLC but it's contents and presentation are amazing under the circumstances.  Well maintained and curated.  All signage in 3 languages (including English).  SLR1000 for foreigners to get in.  The history and culture of Sri Lanka/Ceylon from 5/6th century BC to today on display.  Strong recommendation as a Must See.

The Colombo National Museum is well worth a visit, takes you for about 2hrs back in time and away from hustle and bustle of Colombo City the museum is huge and I think it is necessary to focus on the Hightlights, a audioguide is available but I preferred to walk just through and stop at fascinating exhibits....I came during morning and the place was full of school classes, so maybe afternoons are better leave time for a walk through the well tended grounds

I was surprised to see the way they have maintained this museum. It is a must visit place for any visitors, easily it would take 3 to 5 hours to see the place, depending on your interest level. The collections were awesome.
Well presented tour of the artefacts through the ages relating to Sri Lanka, starting with prehistoric periods. Housed in former Governor's mansion which in itself is interesting to visit.
This for us The National Museum is a must visit.  It is a well laid out museum that takes the visitor through various epochs in the history of the country.

Time well-spent here. A marvellous collection of ancient Sri Lankan culture and history. The Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa sections were superb. Ancient collections of jewellery, pottery, costumes, masks, etc were insightful. Reserve an entire morning or afternoon for the museum. We missed the natural museum as we ran out of time.

The Colombo National Museum building is historically fascinating, it‚Äôs a huge white colonial mansion with well-maintained large courtyard and balconies. The place is quite big and allowed plenty time to explore and enjoy. Inside of it contains all manner of art, carvings and statuary from ancient past of Sri Lanka, and swords, guns and other paraphernalia from the colonial period as well. The collection is well presented and of course impressive. This is one of perfect places in Colombo to visit for the tourist.

Nice building, but really doesn't have much interesting stuff except a bunch of Buddhas from different eras. Couple of cool gold artifacts and Portuguese, Dutch, and British relics, but not worth the price in my opinion.

This is worth a visit. It's well signed inside and takes the tourist through the ages of Sri Lankan history. There are some interesting pieces to see. Take your time and sit down when you can. You can take photos. Great value, the revered tree outside is astonishing. This is ideal for children as well .

Have spent 10 days in Sri Lanka we decided to visit the national museum on our final day in the country. The museum is very well laid out and details the history of the country over time from ancient civilisations to British rule and the return to Sri Lankan independence. This should be a must see site for any tourist visiting Colombo

Dear all if you're going to visit sri lanaka you must visit Colombo national museum Because you can see all Sri Lankan historical things and ancient things there You need to take a ticket to enter You have nice parking space as well This is one of perfect places in Colombo

So it's not of the interactive modern style, useful for children that we may expect on some parts of the world, but it is a great old building with some prize exhibits and useful background at the start of your Sri Lanka trip. We saw wonderful gold and carvings, informative photos and ivory boxes etc. Combined ticket with the Natural History is also worth having.
A great one stop to appreciate the Sri Lanka history and culture. We especially like the natural history section, nicely presented.

Housed in a lovely building surrounded by well maintained grounds. This museum offered a concise but comprehensive history of the country. Displays and artefacts are easily viewed and accompanied in 3 languages. Outside is a cafe and a large,air con, well stocked gift store which surprisingly is not way over priced.

The collection is well presented and range is impressive. The building itself is historically fascinating: huge white colonial mansion with courtyard (unfortunately not accessible for visitors) and balconies. The place is quite big and follows a oneway system, allow generous time to explore and enjoy.

The place Looks promising from a distance but hardly anything inside. Disorganized and messy. Construction and painting works restricts the smooth movement of tourists. Appeared like the museum of a zoology department of a science degree college. Highly priced entry tickets for visitors as well as their vehicles.
If you are interested in knowing the history of Sri Lanka, then you should visit this place..well maintained. Amazing historical wapens.

An impressive collection covering millennia of Sri Lankan history.  Well laid out and easy to wander through,  trilingual text panels make for an easy read for English speakers.  Upper floor can get quite warm in the afternoon, so be prepared and hydrate.
Very good museum, spacious, clean and very informative for all things SL. Would definitely visit again
The museum contain lots of artifice and descriptions is clear in English.  Worth the visit but natural museum? Please pass it. Unless the open the sperm whale bone to public.

This is a great place to learn about Sri Lankan history and culture over a long period of time. This is a place worth visiting for both kids and adults alike. Only problem here is, management doesn't look professional enough. Over the years , management hardly done a thing to improve the facility, But there is a new section with modern technology and displays which shows the future may will look bright for the National Museum.

The National Museum! Sounds important and it should be! But unfortunately not for the people who manage it. The place is filled with many historical artifacts of Sri Lanka and at the same time no proper facilities such as toilets or wheelchair access, etc are provided. As in many Sri Lankan places of interest it's all about how you charge the visitors and not how you provide them the even the basics of facilities! The people of Sri Lanka (who are famous for their hospitality) should be working in there and not the Aliens I saw there who seems to be not aware on how to respond or smile!

One of the best museums I've seen in the country. The exposition is perfectly arranged a clear path through the rooms and all texts in multiple languages. Pictures are allowed and the staff is very friendly. I have learned a great deal about the country, it's history and culture. Nevertheless, I was missing an overview with the countries timeline and more intimation about the recent times.
Many items of historical value are available. Describe the evolution of Sri Lankan culture from the era of kings.

I am not a museum kind of person. But having many hours ahead of our flight we decided to visit the museum. I must say that it was a very informative visit. It is a Long history lesson and there were so much to see and read. It could have been a better visit if the museum was airconditioned and brighter lightings were used. The condition of the parking area was very in need of resurfacing. And toilets were not availed. I almost went into the toilet outside the museum meant for local guests. It was so smelly I couldn't step foot in it.  I hope the authority will dignify the country by addressing these shortfalls.

I did enjoy learning more about Sri Lanka by visiting this museum. There's no air conditioner, but fans inside kept the air flowing. Exhibits give a good window into life and culture from prehistoric to near modern times. Scale models also demonstrate the advanced engineering they used centuries ago.

By world standards, a very average museum. We paid 1000 rupee each to visit (tourists pay, locals dont). It's almost an Ikea experience where once you start, you can't get out until you have past everything. There are 2 buildings in the complex and I would have thought an entrance ticket to the "museum" would have been to both buildings, but no, you then have to pay another 400 rupee to get into the second building. At the original ticket office, this was not explained where we could have purchased a multi ticket for 1200. The money was not an issue, basically just a tourist rip-off and we will not be part of it.

The museum has about 10 sections and the building is majestic on its own. Sections include anuradhapura era, pollonaruwa  era, Kandy era, oil paintings, normal paintings, village life and many more. Can easily spend a day learning about the marvelous craftsmanship of our country. Was fascinated and enjoyed it thoroughly . But wish there were more resting points.

Good place to learn more about the history of Sri Lanka. Huge collection of Buddha statues and artefacts with English explanation, house in a beautiful Colonial Style building. Need at least one hour. LKR1000 for one museum and LKR1200 for combination of 2 museums. Really worth a visit.

Quite interesting to see some of the artefacts in the museum. Well layed out and easy to navigate. They have an app you can down load on the museum (but I could only get the begining to work but that is probably my fault as I am not very tech savvy). Wouldn't say it is a must see but we had two days in Colombo so was good to do for 1-2 hours and then visit beautiful Viharamahadevi park.

Though Colombo is far from the most attractive location in Sri Lanka to visit, don't skip it or at least reserve half a day to visit the National Museum there. There are hardly any museums in the country and those which are there have a limited collection (which isn't always best preserved). Those artifacts which didn't end up in a foreign museum are more or less assembled in the National Museum in Colombo. Therefore one gets the best impression of Sri Lanka's ancient history in Colombo.
no need of any machine to time travel to past this is the place to be supper historical artifacts take you through to past times relaxing place should visit at least once cheers
The exhibits are quite good in this very traditional museum.  It's not really kid friendly, but history buffs will find it well worth a visit.

Colombo National Museum is a good start point for knowing Sri Lanka and its history. The Museum is full of artifacts from different Lankan eras. Although I spent 6-7 hours in the Museum and tried to read as many posted placards on history as possible, yet I couldn't get enough of this beautiful country's glorious past and ups & downs over the centuries!!! Despite the fact that Museum wasn't air conditioned and Sri Lankan sultry weather couldn't be tamed by those old colonial pedestal fans being used inside the museum we still enjoyed the visit and learned a fair deal about Sri Lanka. Huge collection of Buddha statues, coins, ceramic, daggers, bows & arrows, swords, guns, silverware, jewelry etc lie in wait for admirers and history buffs & students. The entry fee SL Rupee 1000/- seem a bit high for one Museum (2nd one is small and not much to see). Museum building is spread over great acreage with its magnificent white color. Lot needs to be done to add beauty and prestige that this Museum deserves. More detail on each item will definitely benefit, and interactive touch screen will help visitors to learn more about Sri Lanka and its history. We had a couple of hours to spend in Colombo and decided to visit the national museum.   Overall the exhibits are organised well, with good explanations of the different artefacts.  We only had time to cover the ground floor, visiting the Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa era galleries, but there was more than enough here to keep our kids engaged for the time we visited.
