Great place to learn about Sri Lankan heritage, I highly recommend a visit here. You can learn a lot about Sri Lankan culture and heritage.

colombo national museum located in albert crescent road . vast area and has a good collection . to know about country's culture and history - museum is best place .its good , but i don't find it interesting - so i won't regret if i would have skip it .

I was keen to learn more about this fascinating country but much of the history on display is about Budda which is pretty much the same story as in all the other Asian Buddhist countries. Saying this it is still worth a visit as the museum building is beautiful and there are some interesting snippets of Sri Lankan history I enjoyed learning about - cost is very reasonable around $7.

We arrived at the National Museum from the rear and bought the combined entry tickets at the Natural History Museum. A short walk around that museum made us wonder if we had wasted our money with tired displays of stuffed animals and half the museum seemingly closed off so it was a degree of trepidation that we walked around to the National Museum. However we were pleasantly surprised to find a really good and informative museum. Most of the galleries had been refurbished over the last 10 years and the exhibits and information filled in a lot of gaps from our earlier visits to historic sights in Sri Lanka. Clearly there is a bit more to go though as the final three rooms were back to the Natural History Museum standard, with almost no information on the interesting items in the rooms.  All in all though worth a visit.

We love visiting museums in the country's we visit however this one was disappointing to say the least. It felt like there was no other history to the country except for Buddha. Would give this a miss.

This is best place get some knowledge about Sri Lankan history. if you want get a guide book  and visit . place is nicely arrange given all the details in brief .  you need 4 to 5 hours get some idea . it is rely good who having interest of studding history well as school kids.

A great collection of artefacts , details and documents which elaborates the very rich heritage of kingdom of Srilanka / Ceylon / Thaprobain also known as Hela diva. Very Neatly arranged to a sequence and descriptive in many languages. Even you can obtain the service of translators in their staff. A place must visit in Colombo and bring your kids with you. Definitely the whole family can enjoy the Musium. Check entry / edit timings. It's 9am to 5pm if I not mistaken.

You can find different displays in this musea, statues from all over the country and from different centuries, but also paintings, coins, battle equipment, agriculture equipment, masks. Done with child who also enjoyed the different rooms
Nice place that you have to visit when you are in Colombo. It might be a bit boring but it's gives you a better understanding of Sri Lanka and it's history.

The exhibits here provide an insight into more than 2000 years of Sri Lankan history. This provides a great context to understand the country but also displays some incredible objects in every gallery. A rare treat at approx $10.

We passed a fun few hours here with 3 kids (6, 5 and 1). It is a grand building, worth seeing in itself. Tickets were inexpensive (1000 per adult, 500 per child above 6 I think as we only paid for our eldest). Some stairs, not certain if access is easy for wheelchair users on that basis but perhaps there is a lift we missed. I loved the textiles and specifically came to view them. The kids were astounded by the stone statuary and we now have a whole new set of bed time questions (are Buddha and God good pals? Who is the eldest? Why do goddesses have 6 arms but I dont?). They had some interesting ceramics but the level of information was frustrating at points. Many items had no age, origin, description etc and it would have been great to know more about how the different pieces of china came to sri lanka. Who used them? Where were the items found? You see lots of more modern copies of the same designs in Sri Lanka...what are the differences in ages and which nationality made the copies?? Although, in general, thr museum could provide a lot more information and context for the exhibitions, we still really enjoyed it. There is even a good cafe for sustenance afterwards. Dont miss the rickshaw/cart display outside by the cafe.
Loved the variety of historical, painting and costume artefacts. Not too busy and lots of information about each area.

This a well laid-out display of important parts of  Srilankan history. The display starts from the Paleolithic era and ends at the recent past (1930-1940). The most impressive part for me as a visitor was from the 12th century until colonisation by Portugal. If I remember correctly, there are some stone works in section 3. This area gives a good overview of how and why stone works were important at that time. They has been used largely to store information, for example land ownership, taxation rights, demarcation points and etc. Also, in day to day live (example toilets, baths) .The details, the precision, the tools available and the material used gives an idea about the knowledge level at that time. The adjacent display was based on craft, jewellery,  weaponry and artefacts. There is a small section dedicated for jewellery worn by kings and queens. It is truly breathtaking. The artists have taken extraordinary care to preserve the original structure of gems embedded, they have handmade minute links connected in multiple dimensions. Some of those jewels are currently in fashion but they are nowhere near what was achieved at that time. You have to see it to understand. This whole room contains the Srilankan craft heritage. Since craft and artistic excellence is a demonstration of how advanced the society is, the ordinary population seems to have lived in a sophisticated healthy society during this time. You will have to allocate three hours to view this complete display.
The Museum is a must. Sri Lanka has an amazing cultural, engineering and intellectual history  going back thousands of years. I had no idea.

On my second last day, we visited here as we had no idea what else to do in Sri Lanka. It's peaceful here and I also manage to sent my postcards as they have a post office next to the enterance. Glad I came here as everything I've learnt in my trip finally all adds up and learnt how Sri Lanka developed from its first settlement. Highly suggest to come here if you want to learnt about their history.

Some of my younger cousins wanted to visit the museum and so we went.Not much of an attraction but it really is very interesting.Packed with lots of different things from different eras, it makes you feel as if you've been transported back to the good old days.A good place  anyone wanting to seek out the countrys history.
Nice place to take some photos and visit the Sri Lanka history... A big big tree live there for more than 100 years.

We enjoyed it here, the museum is very large and extensive with some lovely displays and Interesting history write ups etc. The museum is very well maintained and clean throughout. Lots of school children which was cute but got a bit crowded in particular areas. I would however recommend going to the restroom in your hotel as the public facilities are very poor and very unhygienic and you have to walk all the way outside near the main entrance to access them (so don't lose your entrance ticket). Despite that we enjoyed our time here and would recommend if museums are your thing.
you Can cover the entire Museum within 2-3 Hrs. If you wish to rush you can cover even within one hour too.
An eclectic mix of things to learn about Sri Lanka. Some great stuff along with the more mundane. Some of the masks were amazing! Definitely worth a stop.
Interesting building however attractiveness of exhibition can't compete with museums in other places (Europe, US & Canada, Japan).

Lots of absolutely fascinating artifacts packed into one building. This is a good place to start before touring Sri Lanka, since it will provide some basic information regarding the different empires and their geographies. As a agricultural geek i was particularly impressed with the working mock-up of the ancient tank system and the sacred harvesting circle, which i was lucky enough to experience in real life during my trip. Definitely helps to situate some of the sites that you will probably come across during your trip, and even enables us outsiders to consider how history has shaped contemporary Sri Lankan culture. Amazing to see the Roman coins and Viking artifacts. Evidence that ancient cultures were strongly interconnected through the Silk Road!

This is a wonderful museum with a great many artefacts. The only downside is that once you start you have to complete the circuit. There is no way out from the middle. We had a melt down with a child with no way to exit and so had to keep going. With smaller children be sure to carry snacks and water definitely not stroller friendly

We took a tuktuk to the museum, they are quite well-known. Then after that we got on another tuktuk and went to Odel department store which was about 900m-1km away. There are some exhibits that are more well-maintained and well-lit than others - the weapons/pottery/tools exhibit is renovated and looks good, the rest of the museum is more old but i love the colonial vibe of the building. Note that there is no airconditioning, we went on a rainy day so it was alright. Im not a history-inclined person so i didnt really enjoy it but those who are will as there is so much explanation to read. Not really kids-friendly though. I like how the museum flows - they label each exhibit area with numbers and you just follow them, each exhibit has an exit that leads to another (eg. 1- history, 2- culture etc.) and in the end you wind up at the exit which has a nice air conditioned large souvenir shop with benches you can sit and some drinks or light snacks you can order. the toilets at the shop are also not too shabby!!!
Beautiful colonial building - restored and looking quite beautiful - well displayed Bronzes - lighting has been improved and a welcome change. Must visit place.

This museum was better than i expected! There were very informative descriptions but sometimes the text was too long for me to digest in one go. But i think history/culture/religion junkies will appreciate a visit to this place alot. Admission is 600LKRupees which is quite reasonable! There is however an exhibit with the masks that sri lankan traditional musical plays use which may frighten some younger children. I attached a picture for reference. That was just one of the more mild ones. There are scarier masks of demons etc. which i couldn't bring myself to take photos of!

The explanations in the nicer building are not very clear. It takes quite a long time to go around and once you start there is no short cut to finish the visit earlier so you have to go through the whole thing. I did not really learn anything there. Only go there if you do not have anything else to do. On the positive side, the big white building is very pretty.

Excellent collections of art and artifacts depicting the richness of Sri Lankan history and culture, but the discriminatory / prejudicial pricing was horrific! Seeing local students allowed to enter at decent (and fair) prices while foreign students were forced to pay multiples more was a souring experience! Adding insult to injury, wealthy Sri Lankans were afforded entry at small fractions of what foreigners from developing countries (and backpackers on small budgets) were required to pay. This prejudicial - and highly discriminatory -approach to pricing must be discarded in the interest of fairness. Either charge everyone the same price -- or charge nobody anything at all. And if one wishes to discriminate, then do so on the basis of one's ability to pay, allowing individuals to self-report and give what they can. This would be the most fair.

Visited the museum with my family and kids.It was just mind blowing experience.The best museum in town to know about the Srilankan history it details. The museum divided into 16 sections/ rooms. Positives :- (1) Known more and in details the Srilankan history. (2) Descriptions of all the exhibits in english is really exploratory. Negative :- (1) Rates of foreigners entrt is 600 and the srilankan locals is only 35. (2) The attitude of the staff is not so cooperative and helping hand for the visitors. Note:- To have a better informative experience In the national museum will be with a guide who can help us to understand in detail.

My personal favourites were the burial methods in the prehistoric room, the last Sri Lankan king's throne and jewels, and the room with clothes and embroidery. Some of the displays with mannequins are a little cheesy and the information signs can be a bit confusing, especially if you don't have a great grasp of Buddhism. It is good to have so much information in English though. We were also surprised to see someone welding in a stairwell that is the main exit from the last gallery, but lucky for us, he stopped to let us past!! Overall, this museum gives a good context to a Sri Lankan holiday through a thorough explanation of the country's history and various cultures.
I did not visit the museum as I was taking a open bus ride through the city. The museum is suppose o be the largest museum in the country and houses many artifacts from the Kandyan rulers.

This is a must see if you are to truly understand the culture of Sri Lanka.  The size of the old temples etc were immense reminded me a bit some of the pyramids in Egypt.  The documention of the exhibits is good - visit - this museum needs to be supported so it can develop further

Not only related to SRI LANKAN history, there are things belongs to other countries and nationalities. As a Sri lankan if you have not visited yet, spare your next free time with your family to see and compare the things what we read in our school History books.

Beautiful building and landscaping around. The place is a little hot as it is not air-conditioned. Some of the exhibits look very tired and in need of sprucing up. Interesting exhibits and displays. Overall - worth an hour's visit but don't expect too much. The entrance fee is LKR600 for a foreigner.
A proper museum visit  will take 4-5 hours and a must visit place in sri lanka. There are several sections.
It is a good place for food.It is a hot place . There are some play area also.One fountain too.Thank you

This museum has nice architecture and is very well maintained. Its quite small and one can finish seeing this is one hour or less. Good to know about Sri lankan history and there are some nice artefacts on display.

This Museum in a large Colonial era building has a suitably dated feel, but the Collection of artefacts is worth seeing. Exhibits are labelled in English and it gives an understanding of the history of this country. It was very hot and humid on our visit - 'AC' is provided by the breeze (if any!) through open windows so be prepared.

A two week tour of beautiful Sri Lanka is aptly capped by a visit to the National Museum in Colombo.  Housed in a vast and impressive building dating from British times, the comprehensive and well curated collection covers the phases of the country's development from ancient times, with explanation of the successive kingdoms, external influences (from at least the ancient Greeks), colonial occupations and religious mingling that have led to today's (at last) stable society.  All exhibits have multilingual captioning making them very accessible to English speakers.  Well worth a visit.

A good preview and overview of the history of Sri Lanka before you travel to the other places of interest. The exhibits are well explained and you can download a mobile app which serves as your audio guide. Statues, sculptures, ancient coins, clothes, armoury, jewelry, paintings ... Definitely a must visit!

We went here late one morning and stayed for a couple of hours, appreciating the cool airflow through the open windows as much as the museum contents.  Most of the displays show the various historic era's of Sri Lanka's past with English labelling.  We later toured Sri Lanka, so it was good to get an understanding of the history of the places we were going to visit.

It costs 600 for entrance which is very reasonable.  I would have loved to pay more and have been in air conditioning. The layout is good and it was all very interesting going from early mad to the 1940's. Some of the exhibits looked a little tired and with no air conditioning you cannot spend as much time as you might want. I would suggest a visit to the souvenir shop before or after it has a coffee shop with free wifi so you can cool down.

It is worthwhile going to this museum... lots to see and well preserved artefacts. High point for us was the complete skeleton of a blue whale... just makes one aware of the smallness of ones own being!

My tour leader suggested I go to the museum on my day alone in Colombo after the remaining tour members had departed. He was very proud of the museum but I found it uninspiring and never ending. Once you have gone through all the rooms the only way out is by retracing your steps back through every room. The ticket also gives entrance to the Natural History Museum at the rear of the main building.  I would not recommend this - it reminded me of the teaching displays Auckland Museum would send to schools in the 1950's and looked like it has not been dusted since then

As said, the exhibits are good and mostly are in high quality presentation with different segments of the sri Lankan history and cultures. If only the museum authority can spruced up the outdoor landscape and install air conditioning at the main hall for the comfort as its certainly too warm and humid which restrict one's to linger longer.

e recently visited the museum with our 2 children aged 10 and 11. we particularly enjoyed the sections on Sri Lankan history as we are rather ignorant on this subject. It was good to explain to the children what was happening in the UK at the time that the ancient Sri Lankans were producing such amazing works of art.  Although there was lots of fans it was very hot inside.

We visited on our last morning stay in Sri Lanka. We only had an hour and a half and could easily have stayed a half day to have a really good look around.  A very good selection of exhibits in a very nice old colonial building.  We were there in April and it was really hot, but during the season I'm sure it will have been cool enough.
Good cross section of art and sculpture from Sri Lanka. Provided some good information about the history of the country.

We came to the museum around 4pm and it was definitely too little time to visit everything that the museum could offer. The collection is really large and definitely you need to come early and spend as much time as you can. It closes at 5pm sharp.

Be prepared as there is no air-conditioning and fans were somewhat limited so it was very hot an suffocating inside. Very friendly staff and many wonderful exhibits and objects. Very clear English texts and explanations which covered so much history

The Colombo Museum as it was called at the beginning was established on 1st January 1877. It founder was Sir William Henry Gregory, the British Governor of Ceylon (Sri Lanka) at the time. The Royal Asiatic Society (CB) was instrumental in bringing to the notice of Gregory on his appointment as Governor in 1872 the need for a public museum with much difficulty the approval of the legislative council was obtained within a year. The Architect of the Public Works Department, J.G. Smither was able to prepare the plans for new structure on Italian architectural style. The construction was completed in 1876 and the Museum commenced it functions in the following year. The Authorities of the museum took various steps to display the cultural and natural heritage of the country for this purpose. With the development of the museum to international level, it earned the status of a national museum during the period of Dr. P. E. P. Deraniyagala. He was able to open up branch museums in Jaffna, Kandy and Ratnapura and a full - fledged Department of National Museums was established in 1942 under the act No. 31. The extension of the number of branch museums has now increased to nine and in addition a school science programme and a mobile museum service are also in operation. This process has further been improved by the arrangement of the galleries of the ground floor in a historical sequence and those of the upper galleries on a thematic basis. ETHNOLOGY DIVISION Ethnology Division There are over one million of museum objects existing in various fields related to the Ethnology Division of the Department of National Museums, and they are categorised in materialise and subjects wise as follows. Coins and Currency, Stone antiquities, Jewellery and Silverware, Steel Implements, Pottery, Brassware, Bronze ware, Arms and Weapons, Ivory Objects, Paintings, Maps and Prints, Textile, Wood Carvings, Lacquered and Wooden Objects	, Ola and Writing Materials, Furniture, China and Glassware, Miscellaneous Archaeological Objects The main functions of the division are collecting objects related with ethnology, carrying out research works on the above collections and publishing them on various subjects, based on Ethnology and Archaeology as well as mounting permanent, temporary and Mobile Exhibitions and Presentation of Educational programs on various subjects in the fields of Ethnology. Anthropology Division The division of anthropology focuses the attention on cultural issues of Sri Lanka community. A huge collection of cultural objects more than 6000 are maintained by the anthropology division. The collection has been categorized as bellows. 1.			Agricultural Objects 2.			Household Utensils 3.			Ritual Objects 4.			Traditional marks 5.			Objects used by Vedda community 6.			Dancing costumes 7.			Musical Instruments 8.			Traditional indoor Games 9.			Weights and measures 10.			Objects used in fisheries 11.			Indigenous Medical objects 12.			Maldivian Objects The Scholars, Students and any other persons who interested in the cultural issues are invited to make use this important collection for their research and studies. Permanent and temporary exhibitions and various educational programmes are conducted by the division on social and cultural issues.

We would have liked to spend more time at the Colombo National Museum if it wasn't so hot that day.  There's no air conditioning.  A few fans were dotted around but air inside the museum was hot and musky.  Museum also lacks atmosphere.  Most staff inside were sitting or standing next to a fan.  A real pity as the collection is very impressive!
This museum has too many relics to breathe in.  It us well designed with a walk taking you from room to room in order.  Relics from the Sri Lanka ancient cities are perhaps the highlight.

We enjoyed this museum so much we spent nearly five hours here.  Some wonderful exhibits really well laid out and maintained, clear English explanations and covering so much history.  Two cafes almost next to each other - one more expensive than the other but both good depending on what type of food you are looking for.  Wonderful building, friendly staff, and not too expensive.
Can see lots of ancient and historical things can feel the old agricultural of Sri Lanka bt they cost tickets
We spent 4 hours in the museum and we really liked the National Museum of Colombo.  The exhibits are filled with objects, the English texts are well written and there are descriptions of art history.

We stayed 3 days at the end of our 2 weeks stay in Sri Lanka and explored Colombo mostly by walking or 3 wheeler. This is an excellent place. Lots of things to see. Sri Lanka is just amazing. Nice cafe inside the premises where you can relax with a good cup of coffee and smoke. Lots of Sri Lanka history artifacts. Interesting place.

The museum is probably one of the most important in Colombo, if not the whole of Sri Lanka.  There are many exhibits and artefacts providing an in-depth and stimulating overview of the History and culture of Sri Lanka.  The building itself is very attractive and colonial in appearance and once in the lobby you are greeted with one of the best preserved statues of Buddha on the island.  The highlight for many is the throne of the last King of Kandy but there are many other things to keep your interest and attention (although the lack of air conditioning can be tiring).  There is a statue of Queen Victoria at the entrance near the road with the inscription "V.F.I 1897 - Diamond Jubilee Memorial".  The museum charges an entrance fee but please remember to pay the extra fee if you want to take photographs.
The museum is good but difficult as it's big and there is no AC and fans were limited so very hot n suffocating inside

I have been to the National Museum in Colombo many times. During the last visit I noticed that they need to do some changes to the place, so that it looks better. However I enjoyed visiting the place with my children.

This is an amazing building with a super interesting collection. Here you see all the artefacts and other attributes that come from all various sites across Sri Lanka. It completes you view once you visit ancient sites. We found it very valuable and it's worth to spend time for a visit!

Quite a lot packed in here, from masks to ceramics to textiles and weapons. A lot to take in and read but overall quite interesting. Not very interactive for kids, more old school but coffee shop and souvenir shop are both good.
We had a great time visiting the museum. They have great exhibits and an amazing shop as well The museum is easy to navigate and it is a nice way to end a tour of Sri Lanka
Start from early man. 16 sections of display on 2 floors. Fabrics weapons, brass figures, stone carvings.

We really enjoyed seeing the art but of course it was VERY warm. It concerned me for the art as the humidity cannot be good for the relics. LOTS of school children were there which we also enjoyed. Really needs some maintenance too.
There's even a throne. It is also fun getting lost in the chattering crowds of school children dressed in white as they zoom through the museum rooms.

The National Museum is reopened now. Great efforts taken up by the government. Though, nothing much for expats to see, this is an ideal place for domestic people plus Lankan well wishers to understand the history while looking at those best collections.
The Museum doesn't have much for the tourists.. We couldn't find someone for assistance. Just a check box in your itenary

column11: I spent a very happy hour here keeping moving pretty briskly.  Wide selection of largely chronologically arranged exhibits and cheerful attendants.  As with everywhere in Sri Lanka, expect to share it with vast crowds of school pupils!

This museum holds an impressive array of collections surrounding Sri Lankan history; culture, religion, technology, warfare, architecture and art. The museum has a pretty good storytelling going on which make the collections enjoyable. The museum has really bad ventilation and was extremely hot the day I was there (before noon). Thats why it wont get a five.

The two things I liked best about our visit was the prehistoric section with bones some 6000 years old and watching the groups of school children visiting the museum.  The museum itself is an old British Mansion, which is quite pretty.  It houses furniture, sculptures, manuscripts, pottery, carvings, masks and pottery in several rooms.  The gift shop is quite nice, and the proceeds from the sales go to help the local people.
Very nice. Gives you the nostalgic feeling of what this place used to be. Lots to see, and take photos of

Can be a little difficult to find for the Tuk tuk drivers... that's another story! In short it's a grand building with lots of artefacts, scary masks and buddhas! Little unorganised in my opinion! They do need air conditioning and need a better approach towards tourists / visitors in general. Also there is no gift shop!
Nice museum.  Something here for everyone.  Fair entry fee.  Set aside one to two hours for this museum.

The museum building looks really very nice from the outside.. This museum of Asian civilization is one of the oldest in Sri Lanka. There is an entrance fee as well as camera fee.  I think is about 600 SL rupees and 250 for camera charges. . The good thing about the museum is that you learn a lot about  the history of Ceylon  (Sri Lanka). One would learn many things about Sri Lankan culture. The field work done by the women and men on the  plantations is beautifully depicted .

It's a quiet place on weekdays, especially when there are no school visits. I'm sure there are better museum around the world but this will help you get a sense of culture and understand the country better. Locals pay a different ticket price. Not the most attractive feature of the museum.

It looks lovely and it's only 600 slr but you need to pay 250 more for photograph pass, vid is more. Tbf I like museums but did not find anything that really interested me here but it has some nice things in it, it's upto you ???

The museum is housed in a lovely old building and is full of interesting displays and artefacts from Sri Lanka history. The displays are well set out in different rooms and there is lots of information about the history of the country. Admission price is reasonable but you need an extra ticket if you want to take photos. Don't miss this attraction.
